page.title: 15Ecology in Lorton
page.content: Low Lorton has hills, a river valley, woods and farmland. With a moderately wet climate, a wide variety of flora and fauna can be seen from the many footpaths in the area. There are coniferous and deciduous trees-larch sycamore and ash. Wild flowers abound, including pyramidal and early purple orchids, primrose, foxgloves and figwort. Red squirrel, deer, badgers, mink and other wild animals can be seen. There are many common birds robins and sparrows, plus less common i.e. buzzards and goosander. The National Trust, L.D.S.P.B. water board and farmers all play a role in the conservation in the area. For example to qualify for grants, farmers must apply to the L.D.S.P.B. for permission to use chemical fertilisers, to erect buildings femces or to drain.
